title: Gravitational compression
text:
Gravitational compression is a phenomenon in which <a href="gravity">gravity</a>, acting on the <a href="mass">mass</a> of an object, compresses it, reducing its size and increasing the object's <a href="density">density</a>. 
At the center of a <a href="planet">planet</a> or <a href="star">star</a>, gravitational compression produces <a href="heat">heat</a> by the <a href="Kelvin%E2%80%93Helmholtz%20mechanism">Kelvin–Helmholtz mechanism</a>. This is the mechanism that explains how <a href="Jupiter">Jupiter</a> continues to <a href="radiation">radiate</a> heat produced by its gravitational compression.
The most common reference to gravitational compression is <a href="stellar%20evolution">stellar evolution</a>. The <a href="Sun">Sun</a> and other <a href="main%20sequence">main-sequence</a> stars are produced by the initial <a href="gravitational%20collapse">gravitational collapse</a> of a <a href="molecular%20cloud">molecular cloud</a>. Assuming the mass of the material is large enough, gravitational compression reduces the size of the core, increasing its <a href="temperature">temperature</a> until <a href="hydrogen%20fusion">hydrogen fusion</a> can begin. This <a href="hydrogen">hydrogen</a>-to-<a href="helium">helium</a> <a href="fusion%20reaction">fusion reaction</a> releases <a href="energy">energy</a> that balances the inward gravitational <a href="pressure">pressure</a> and the star becomes stable for millions of years. No further gravitational compression occurs until the hydrogen is nearly used up, reducing the thermal pressure of the fusion reaction. At the end of the Sun's life, gravitational compression will turn it into a <a href="white%20dwarf">white dwarf</a>.
At the other end of the scale are <a href="Stellar%20evolution%23Massive%20stars">massive stars</a>. These stars burn their fuel very quickly, ending their lives as <a href="supernova">supernova</a>e, after which further gravitational compression will produce either a <a href="neutron%20star">neutron star</a> or a <a href="black%20hole">black hole</a> from the remnants.
For planets and <a href="natural%20satellite">moons</a>, equilibrium is reached when the gravitational compression is balanced by a pressure gradient. This pressure gradient is in the opposite direction due to the strength of the material, at which point gravitational compression ceases.
